headline: Doctors canvass innovative ways to solve Africa’s health challenges
summarized_story:
Two medical entrepreneurs, Dr Yetunde Ayo-Oyalowo and Dr Funmi Adewara, have called for innovative strategies to combat the problem of universal access to health care in Africa.
Both doctors, who are female inventors of accessible healthcare services, also emphasised the need for solutions that were affordable, easy-to-reach, sustainable and efficient to solve the challenges in the healthcare sector.
“I felt ordinary people do not have access to health care.
I once worked in a health insurance company and I discovered that even with the reduced price only a little percentage of people could afford health insurance and health insurance is a sort of gateway to good health care.
So, I thought what happens to the man on the street, how will they be able to access health care?

headline: Killings: Perpetrators must be swiftly punished, says Lalong
summarized_story:
Governor Simon Lalong of Plateau State, on Saturday, expressed worry over the incessant attacks and killings by gunmen in different parts of the state.
Within the past two weeks, findings by Sunday PUNCH showed that about 30 people had been killed in different attacks by gunmen, who also destroyed properties.
The latest incident was on Thursday when gunmen killed more than six people in Jos South and Riyom local government areas of the state.
The governor, therefore, ordered the security agencies to do everything possible to arrest persons disrupting the peace of the state.
Our expectation is that these attacks will not only be prevented, but whenever any is recorded, the perpetrators will be swiftly arrested and brought to justice.’’ ,,Copyright PUNCH.

headline: Sadiq Abdullahi presents agenda for Sports development
summarized_story:
By Jacob AjomA former Nigeria tennis star, Sadiq Abdullahi has been ruminating on the problems hindering the development of tennis and sports generally in the country and has put forward suggestions he believes if well implemented could move sports in the country forward.
In a ten-point write-up he titled ‘My thoughts on tennis and sports in Nigeria’, Abdullahi who is an adjunct professor of global education and curriculum development and improvement at Florida International University in Miami, Florida, USA, observed that the recently concluded Nigerian Olympian Association AGM in Abuja was an eye-opener as it had exposed to him some of the challenges militating against sports development in the country.
He, however, insisted that the challenges were surmountable and “the time to act is now”.
If we cannot, we must at least control the effect.”Most importantly, the former Olympian said, “We must shift emphasis from competitions to grassroots sports development.” He also called for a comprehensive 15 to 20 years tennis development plan.
Vanguard News Nigeria

headline: Army chief rejigs Generals, names principal staff officers, field commanders
summarized_story:

headline: Now, in remembrance of things that have come
summarized_story:
What follows are excerpts from a piece in 2014 commemorating the centenary of amalgamation of the Southern and Northern protectorates of Nigeria.
“With the equipoise of contending regional titans and their perfectly weighed prejudices and preferences, it was impossible to unify and homogenize the emergent national elite.
But ignoring the political realities and contending cultural milieu, he chose to attack the problem frontally by attempting to bypass the northern feudal lords to reach the people directly.
Yet by virtue of the same cultural logic the mutiny by mid-ranking officers of mainly Igbo origins was so politically clueless, so motivated by bloodthirsty and irrational vengeance, that it became part of the national problem.

headline: Microblogging and the Nigerian State: Matters Arising

However, Nigerians generally believed that the government responded to Twitter’s decision to delete a tweet by the Nigerian President where he was alleged to have threatened violence against a section of the country.

It is this inherent capacity of social media enterprises to sway collective opinion and subtly affect people’s decisions that make social media institutions as dangerous as they are liberating.

headline: 10 family members die after eating local meal in Zamfara
summarized_story:
Ten members of the same family have died as a result of eating poisonous food in Jangeme village of Gusau Local Government Area in Zamfara State.
A neighbour of the deceased family members, Malam Sama’ila Sani, informed The PUNCH that they were served with guinea corn food called ‘tuwon dawa’ in Hausa, which was allegedly cooked by one of the members of the family, Aisha Musa.
According to Sani, immediately the family members ate the food, they developed stomach cramps and were rushed to a hospital in Gusau, where they later died.
“Immediately after eating the food, all of them began to feel serious stomach discomfort and were later rushed to the hospital in Gusau; but, unfortunately, they all died,” Sani explained to our correspondent.
Confirming the incident, the spokesperson of Yariman Bakura Specialist Hospital, Gusau, Auwal Usman Ruwan-Doruwa, said the victims died as a result of food poisoning.

headline: South African court sets date for Jacob Zuma’s jail appeal
summarized_story:
Agency ReportsA South African court on Saturday agreed to hear ex-president Jacob Zuma’s challenge to a 15-month jail term for failing to attend a corruption hearing.
The constitutional court had on Tuesday given Zuma 15 months in jail for absconding in February from the inquiry led by Deputy Chief Justice Raymond Zondo.
Zuma had until the end of Sunday to hand himself in, but on Saturday the court agreed to hear his application, suspending the order.

Zuma also faces a separate court case relating to a $2 billion arms deal in 1999 when he was deputy president.

headline: Full Throttle: England Boss Southgate Says No Rotation in Euro Quarterfinal with Ukraine
summarized_story:
Gareth Southgate said it would be “an insult to Ukraine” for England to rotate their lineup due to the possibility of four players missing a potential Euro 2020 semifinal.
However, asked by ESPN whether the yellow card situation would affect his team selection against Andriy Shevchenko’s side, Southgate replied:“No.
I understand that strategically you might like to do that but I can’t think of a country in the world that would do that for a quarterfinal.
No, I think we’ve got to focus on tomorrow.
I think it would be a big error for us to be thinking about anything else and I think it would be an insult to Ukraine as well.

headline: About 200 US Companies Hit By ‘Colossal’ Cyber-attack
summarized_story:
About 200 US businesses have been hit by a “colossal” ransomware attack, according to a cyber-security firm.
The cyber-breach emerged on Friday afternoon as companies across the US were clocking off for the long Independence Day weekend.
Kaseya said in its statement that a “small number” of companies had been affected, though Huntress Labs said the number is already about 200 and counting.
“This is a colossal and devastating supply chain attack,” Huntress Labs’ senior security researcher John Hammond said in an email to Reuters news agency.
The group sometimes threatens to post stolen documents on its website – known as the “Happy Blog” – if victims don’t comply with its demands.

headline: Europe in Vaccination Race Against Covid′s Delta Variant
summarized_story:
Countries across Europe are scrambling to accelerate coronavirus vaccinations and outpace the spread of the more infectious delta variant, in a high-stakes race to prevent hospital wards from filling up again with patients fighting for their lives.
The risk of infection from the delta variant is “high to very high” for partially or unvaccinated communities, according to the European Centre for Disease Control, which monitors 30 countries on the continent.
In the U.K., cases of the delta variant have increased fourfold in less than a month, with confirmed cases Friday up 46% on the previous week.
France lifted the last of its major restrictions Wednesday, allowing unlimited crowds in restaurants, at weddings and most cultural events despite fast-rising cases of the delta variant.
But Dr. Hans Kluge, the head of the WHO’s Europe office, cautioned this week that the delta variant is poised to become dominant by August in the 53-country region his office covers.

headline: Southern Nigeria Governors to Meet on Open Grazing and Restructuring Monday in Lagos
summarized_story:
Seventeen governors of Nigeria’s southern states will on Monday converge on Lagos for the second time this year to continue their search for solution to the myriad of problems confronting the country.
The source said: “The governors are working towards a better Southern Nigeria within the Nigerian nation.
The southern governors will be looking at the gains of the last meeting and come up with their next move.
“You know the southern governors agreed that the progress of the nation requires that urgent and bold steps be taken towards the restructuring of the Nigerian federation leading to the devolution of power.
During the first meeting in Asaba, the southern governors resolved to ban all forms of open grazing in the southern states of the country.

The two officials also discussed US plans to increase assistance for Indonesia’s broader COVID-19 response efforts, the statement said.
Penny K Lukito, the chief of Indonesia’s food and drug agency, said earlier on Friday it authorised the Moderna vaccine for emergency use.
The company said the vaccine was far more effective in producing antibodies against the Delta variant than it was against the Beta variant first identified in South Africa.
Indonesia has relied mainly on the vaccine from China’s Sinovac, but has been looking to diversify supply sources.
